choices.A: One-to-one NAT IP pool is used in the firewall policy.
choices.B: Destination NAT is disabled in the firewall policy.
choices.C: Port block allocation IP pool is used in the firewall policy.
choices.D: Overload NAT IP pool is used in the firewall policy.

discussion.content: Actually this question appear to me very strange. Answers A,C,D have the same same session table as the one showed, it is not possible to say one-to-one so easy, since, you can configure SNAT overload with preserve source port. One thing, no destination NAT IP is showed, this means any VIP is configured in the firewall policy and this means is something "disabled" in such policy, even if I admit is a bit stretched thought.

since all packets have the same source IP (10.0.1.10), one-to-one NAT should behave the same as an overload pool since there's no need to apply PAT or share the pool. I think the only fact we're sure about is that there is no DNAT...

Selected Answer: A
A. One-to-one NAT IP pool is used in the firewall policy. 

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html

Selected Answer: A
A "one-to-one" is correct, See FortiGate Security 7.0 Study Guide P.164 "In one-to-one NAT, PAT is not required. Same source port is shown for both the ingress and egress address called also a single mapping of an internal to a external address"

comments.content: A and C would have been correct only if the port of the source remained same through the http and https connection

discussion.content: i tested this now in firewall. both A and C are correct. they show the similar output when i checked the session table. always do the lab and verify.

Selected Answer: A
A ......
I may be missing something? Wouldn't it be Overload because of the numerous ports used in Source-NAT?

comments.content:
In the one-to-one pool type, an internal IP address is mapped with an external address on a first-come, firstserved basis. 
There is a single mapping of an internal address to an external address. Mappings are not fixed and, if there are no more addresses available, a connection will be refused.
Also, in one-to-one, PAT is not required. In the example on this slide, you can see the same source port is shown for both the ingress and egress address.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Fortigate Security 7.0 Page 164

comments.content: Yes, the port translation shows it's not PAT, therefore it's one to one

discussion.content: is this correct ?

choices.A: You can configure only two SLA targets per one Performance SLA.
choices.D: SLA targets are used only when referenced by an SD-WAN rule.
choices.C: SLA targets are required for SD-WAN rules with a Best Quality strategy.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are correct about SLA targets? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
A incorrect - You can configure more that 2 SLA targets
C incorrect - SLA targets only required for Lower Cost (SLA) and Maximize Bandwidth (SLA)

Selected Answer: BD
Correct:
B. SLA targets are optional.
D. SLA targets are used only when referenced by an SD-WAN rule. 
Incorrect:
A. You can configure only two SLA targets per one Performance SLA. (more is possible)
C. SLA targets are required for SD-WAN rules with a Best Quality strategy. (not required)

https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.4.14/administration-guide/580649/link-health-monitor
"If the health check is used in an SD-WAN rule that uses Manual or Best Quality strategies, enabling SLA Target is optional. If the health check is used in an SD-WAN rule that uses Lowest Cost (SLA) or Maximum Bandwidth (SLA) strategies, then SLA Target is enabled."

https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.4.14/administration-guide/382233/sla-targets-example
"Enable SLA Targetsand configure the constraints. To add multiple SLA targets, use the CLI."

Download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html

Selected Answer: BC
Just testing Sla now, for Best Quality SLA are required, it's a little bit obvies, how you can judge what link are best without a parameter?

comments.content:
Best quality: needs quality “criteria”
Low cost: needs SLA “target”

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Correct answers are B and C.
Just tested it and for Best Quality the Target SLA is required.

choices.D: The session is in FIN_ACK state.
choices.A: The session is in SYN_SENT state.
choices.B: The session is in FIN_WAIT state.
choices.C: The session is in ESTABLISHED state.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. The session is in SYN_SENT state.

https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Troubleshooting-Tip-FortiGate-session-table-information/ta-p/196988

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html
FG Study Guide Security page 191

Selected Answer: A
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Troubleshooting-Tip-FortiGate-session-table-information/ta-p/196988

Selected Answer: A
Ans is A coz In the first line "Session info: proto=6 proto_state=02"

comments.content: UDP is Proto=17. Proto=6 is TCP

discussion.content: A = because Proto= 6 (UDP) so proto_state = 02 is SYN_SENT
Security Guide Page 187

Selected Answer: A
Indeed, it is A, the link below has a table for all the states:

https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Troubleshooting-Tip-FortiGate-session-table-information/ta-p/196988

Hi! the article https://kb.fortinet.com/kb/viewContent.do?externalId=FD30042 it´s a little bit confuse... because, as the picture shows... the "Expire timer" is 3600... as State=STABLISHED, but the VALUE = 2 (SYS_SENT).

questions.question_text: Which statement is correct regarding the inspection of some of the services available by web applications embedded in third-party websites?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. FortiGate can inspect sub-application traffic regardless where it was originated. 

FortiGate Security 7.2 Study Guide (p.302)
"FortiOS gives administrators all the tools they need to inspect sub-application traffic."

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html
answer is D which from NSE4 7.0 test

Selected Answer: D
Sec gude pg 436
FortiOS gives administrators all the tools they need to inspect sub-application traffic

Selected Answer: D
Fortigate_Security_Guide

discussion.content: Respuesta D, Guia de Estudio Seguridad Fortigate 7.0, Pagina 436

choices.D: FortiGate can inspect sub-application traffic regardless where it was originated.
choices.B: The application signature database inspects traffic only from the original web application server.
choices.C: FortiGuard maintains only one signature of each web application that is unique.
choices.A: The security actions applied on the web applications will also be explicitly applied on the third-party websites.

questions.question_text: Which engine handles application control traffic on the next-generation firewall (NGFW) FortiGate?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A. Intrusion prevention system engine

FortiGate Security 7.2 Study Guide (p.296):
"Application control can be configured in proxy-based and flow-based firewall policies. However, because application control uses the IPS engine, which uses flow-based inspection, inspection is always flow-based."
"It uses an IPS engine to analyze network traffic and detect application traffic, even if the application is using standard or non-standard protocols and ports."

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html
Correct answer is A.

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer. https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.0.0/handbook/72943/application-control
Respuesta A, Guia de Estudio de Seguridad 7.0 Pagina 430
